channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Infighting Rips Through the Pro-Kremlin Blogosphere
item.description: Some military bloggers are viciously accusing others of favoring Ukraine in the war.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times

item.title: Ukrainians Shun a Church Seen as a Kremlin Tool
item.description: The village parishioners’ decision to oust their priest reflects a broader push within Ukraine to reduce the influence of an Orthodox church that answers to Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Yurii Shyvala
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Parishioners leaving church after a service in Blystavytsya, Ukraine. The village has switched its allegiance from the Russian Orthodox Church to the Ukrainian national church.

item.title: Colombia Rebel Group ELN and Government Begin Cease-Fire
item.description: A six-month truce began on Thursday between the government and the largest remaining insurgency, the far-left group known as the National Liberation Army.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Federico Rios Escobar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Graffiti indicating the presence of E.L.N. guerrillas in Anorí, a town in the Antioquia region of Colombia.

item.title: Niger Coup: Here’s What to Know
item.description: Amid an unpredictable military coup, neighboring countries have threatened to go to war — some to scuttle the coup, and others to ensure its success.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Protesters cheering Nigerien troops in front of the French Embassy in Niamey during a demonstration that followed a rally in support of the junta on Sunday.

item.title: 14 Injured in Stabbing and Car Rampage Near Seoul
item.description: Less than a month after another mass stabbing, 13 victims were sent to the hospital in a similar incident that also included five people being hit by a car. The episode is being treated as a “terrorist act.”
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Rescue workers at a scene where at least 14 people were injured on Thursday in a stabbing and car rampage in a Seoul suburb.

item.title: Canada Prime Minister, Justin Trudeau, Separates From Wife, Sophie Grégoire
item.description: The Canadian prime minister and his wife have been married for 18 years and share three children.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada and his wife, Sophie Grégoire, in Ottawa in March.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Home Scaled by Greenpeace Protesters in Britain
item.description: The incursion by opponents of oil drilling raised concerns about the security of the British leader and his family.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A photograph provided by Greenpeace UK shows activists climbing up to the roof of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s home in North Yorkshire.

item.title: South Korean Ferry Disaster Figure Yoo Hyuk-kee Is Extradited
item.description: Yoo Hyuk-kee’s family company ran the Sewol ferry, whose sinking off the South Korean coast left hundreds dead. Prosecutors have charged Mr. Yoo, a U.S. resident, with embezzlement.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Yoo Hyuk-kee, center, at Incheon International Airport in South Korea on Friday.

item.title: Under Fire and Understaffed: Doctors
item.description: Positioned close to the front lines, temporary medical posts are a critical lifeline for the constant inflow of soldiers hurt in the counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Emile Ducke
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: Hundreds Fall Ill From Heat at World Scout Jamboree in South Korea
item.description: As the country endures its hottest summer in years, at least 125 people were hospitalized and many others were treated for symptoms during baking conditions at the World Scout Jamboree.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Participants for the 25th World Scout Jamboree arriving at a camping site in Buan County, South Korea, on Tuesday.

item.title: How Richard Beauvais and Eddie Ambrose Discovered They’d Been Switched at Birth
item.description: Two Canadian men who were switched at birth to families of different ethnicities are now questioning who they really are and learning how racial heritage shapes identities.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times; Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times

item.title: Iranians Blame Power Grid and Gas Shortage for Shutdown Amid Heat
item.description: The government in Tehran cited “unprecedented” heat when it ordered a two-day shutdown to protect health and conserve energy, but many residents were not buying it.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:description: A dried-out riverbed in Isfahan, Iran.

item.title: Paris Bookstalls Are Told to Relocate During Next Year’s Olympics
item.description: The “bouquinistes” along the River Seine have objected after being told that most of them will have to move temporarily for security reasons.
item.dc:creator: Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle and Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Chris Carmichael for The New York Times
item.media:description: Booksellers along the Seine in Paris have been told they will have to relocate during next summer’s Olympic Games.

item.title: Who Is Shikma Bressler, the Face of Israel’s Protests?
item.description: Shikma Bressler, a mother of five who says her passion is life in the lab, has emerged as a symbol of the struggle against the government’s divisive judicial overhaul.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: “It’s rare that you recognize you are in a real-time historical moment,” Shikma Bressler said.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Donald Trump’s day in court.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Australians’ ‘Golden Ticket’ to the U.S.
item.description: Proposed changes to the E-3 visa have worried some expatriates.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrons at Ruby’s Cafe, an Australian coffee shop in Manhattan.

item.title: Meta Removes News From Platform in Canada
item.description: A Canadian law that will require tech companies to compensate domestic publishers has led Meta to start blocking news articles on its social networks.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Meta has followed through with a threat to restrict access to news content in protest of a new Canadian law.

item.title: Russia’s Pro-War Bloggers Are Suddenly Sniping Among Themselves
item.description: A new tone has set in among the uninhibited military bloggers, whose support for the invasion has given them unusual powers to speak out.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian solder in a kindergarten near the front line in the Donetsk region of Ukraine on Wednesday.

item.title: Winter Heat Wave Grips Chile, Argentina and Other South American Countries
item.description: An unusual winter heat wave has brought record high temperatures to cities across Argentina, Chile and Paraguay this week, triggering concerns about the impacts of climate change.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez and Natalie Alcoba
item.media:description: Buenos Aires broke an 81-year-old daily temperature record on Tuesday.

item.title: Seiichi Morimura, 90, Who Exposed Japanese Wartime Atrocities, Dies
item.description: In a widely read book, he detailed gruesome biological experiments on people at a secret Imperial Army site in occupied China before and during World War II.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Seiichi Morimura at his desk in Tokyo in 2015. A mystery novelist, he began investigating Japanese army medical experiments after a former participant in the program contacted him.

item.title: 2 U.S. Navy Sailors Charged With Spying for China
item.description: Prosecutors said the two sailors in California gave Chinese intelligence officers U.S. military secrets and sensitive information.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Jill Cowan
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: One of the two Navy sailors accused of spying was assigned to a ship based at Naval Base San Diego. The charges appear to reflect the Chinese government’s deep interest in the U.S. Navy’s Pacific Fleet.

item.title: Poland and Lithuania Warn Against ‘Provocations’ From Wagner in Belarus
item.description: The notice came a few days after two helicopters bearing Belarusian flags violated Polish airspace.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: President Gitanas Nauseda of Lithuania, left, and Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki of Poland during a news conference on Thursday in northeastern Poland, near both countries’ borders with Belarus.

item.title: Australia Will Return Looted Sculptures to Cambodia
item.description: A centuries-old Buddhist sculpture was taken from a rural area in Cambodia nearly 30 years ago. It was later sold with two other statues to the National Gallery of Australia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: via The National Gallery of Australia
item.media:description: Bronze sculptures of Bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara Padmapani and attendants, which will be returned from Australia to Cambodia.

item.title: The Art of Telling Forbidden Stories in China
item.description: Many writers are looking for ways to capture the everyday realities that the government keeps hidden — sometimes at their own peril.
item.dc:creator: Han Zhang
item.media:credit: Tommy Kha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hao Qun and an unnamed writer. Hao, who once enjoyed a successful writing career in China, fled to Australia after facing persecution.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: The future of U.S. politics after Donald Trump’s indictment.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times

item.title: VanMoof’s Bankruptcy Worries Owners of Electric Bikes
item.description: VanMoof’s sleek electric bikes attracted fans, but the Dutch company’s demise has left owners unable to get repairs and worried that app-enabled functions may stop working.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cyclist on a VanMoof bike in Amsterdam. The maker of electric bicycles declared bankruptcy last month.

item.title: ‘Kill the Boer’ Song Fuels Backlash in South Africa and U.S.
item.description: Right-wing commenters claim that an old anti-apartheid chant is a call to anti-white violence, but historians and the left-wing politician who embraces it say it should not be taken literally.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Julius Malema gesturing from the stage on Saturday during the 10th anniversary celebrations of his political party in Johannesburg.

item.title: A Leader of Niger’s Coup Visits Mali, Raising Fears of a Wagner Alliance
item.description: Several military officials who took power from the president in Niger last week met with the leaders of Mali, where the Kremlin-backed Wagner mercenary group has deployed about 1,500 troops.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Office of the President of Mali
item.media:description: In this photograph released by the Malian presidency, Assimi Goïta, center, Mali’s interim president, met on Wednesday in Bamako, the capital, with Gen. Salifou Modi, left, one of the military leaders who ousted the president of Niger last week.

item.title: Are the Trump Indictments a Turning Point? History Says Not Likely.
item.description: The latest indictment of former President Donald J. Trump takes the United States to an uncharted place in its history. But other countries’ histories suggest that the prosecution of leaders accused of wrongdoing cannot fix underlying problems.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (2020 Election Case)
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump at a rally for his 2024 presidential campaign in Erie, Pa., on Saturday.

item.title: Amid Signs of a Covid Uptick, Researchers Brace for the ‘New Normal’
item.description: Infections remain very low, despite signs of a slight increase. Now, experts are looking for clues to what living with the coronavirus will be like this winter and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nearly all Americans have built up multiple layers of immunity following repeated infections, immunizations or both, so the virus is unlikely to cause the harm this winter that was seen in previous seasons.

item.title: Ukrainian Troops Trained by the West Stumble in Battle
item.description: Ukraine’s army has for now set aside U.S. fighting methods and reverted to tactics it knows best.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a Ukrainian mortar team from the 24th Mechanized Brigade fired on a Russian position in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine last month.

item.title: As Russia Strikes Ports, Ukraine Scrambles to Continue Grain Exports
item.description: Their grain and sunflower oil once helped feed the world. Now, even their backup routes to the international market have become targets.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grain stored in Moloha, in the Odesa region. Ukraine once sold over 10 percent of the world’s wheat, barley and corn, much of it via Odesa.

item.title: Erdogan Urges Resumption of Grain Deal in Call With Putin
item.description: The Turkish president urged a resumption of the agreement that allowed Ukraine to ship grain through the Black Sea, and called on both Russia and Ukraine not to escalate tensions.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur, Ivan Nechepurenko and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said that Turkey was working to restore the Black Sea deal, which it helped broker along with the United Nations last summer.

item.title: Ukraine Says Russia Launched Overnight Drone Attacks on Kyiv
item.description: Moscow launched at least 10 drones at the city, with an administrative building among those damaged by debris from interceptions, local officials said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A building in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, showing scars on Wednesday after the attacks.

item.title: Xi’s Abrupt Shake-Up of Nuclear Force’s Leaders Fans Speculation
item.description: The Chinese leader’s replacement of two commanders has fanned speculation about corruption or failings in the force that manages China’s nuclear missiles.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, unveiled the Rocket Force’s new commander, Wang Houbin, top left, and its new political commissar, Xu Xisheng, top right, in a photo released by the state news agency, Xinhua.

item.title: City in Mexico Bans Performances of Songs With Misogynistic Lyrics
item.description: The city of Chihuahua said it would impose hefty fines on bands that perform songs with lyrics that “promote violence against women.”
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: A march for women’s rights in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, in March. The country has been grappling with a rise in killings of women in recent year.

item.title: Can a Rapper Change Italy’s Mind About Migrants?
item.description: As the country’s right-wing government takes a hard line on Mediterranean immigration, the hip-hop artist Ghali has become a prominent voice of compassion.
item.dc:creator: Alia Malek
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Andrea Frazzetta for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ghali at a recording studio in Milan in June.

item.title: Read Your Way Through Hanoi
item.description: Hanoi, long a city of storytellers, has been devastated and reborn time and time again. Nguyễn Phan Quế Mai guides readers through the literature that has played a part in that renewal.
item.dc:creator: Nguyễn Phan Quế Mai

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Donald Trump faces significant new federal charges.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jack Smith, the special counsel overseeing the investigation, filed charges against former President Donald J. Trump in connection with his efforts to remain in power after losing the 2020 election.

item.title: Pope Francis Heads to Portugal for Catholic Church’s Youth Day
item.description: The pope will preside over a gathering of young people from around the world, mindful that the changes he has initiated in the Roman Catholic Church will depend on them.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Miguel A. Lopes
item.media:description: Pope Francis waving to the crowd on Wednesday outside the Apostolic Nunciature in Lisbon.

item.title: Kenya Offers to Lead International Force to Help Restore Order in Haiti
item.description: Kenya has offered to lead a police force to help restore order to Haiti, where gangs that control vast parts of the country’s capital have fomented violence.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Tires were set on fire by the police during a protest in January in Port-au-Prince after a gang attack on a police station that left six officers dead.

item.title: Iran Orders Two-Day Shutdown Because of ‘Unprecedented’ Heat
item.description: The government announced a two-day public holiday, ordering all government agencies, banks and schools to close amid soaring temperatures that threatened public health and strained the power grid.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: In Iran’s capital, Tehran, the temperature was expected to reach 104 degrees Fahrenheit (40 Celsius) in the coming days, the country’s metrological organization said.

item.title: 2 Drone Strikes in Moscow in 2 Days and a Message: Russia Is Not Safe
item.description: The same building housing Russian government offices was hit twice within 48 hours.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko, Alina Lobzina and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: A building in central Moscow was struck by a drone on Tuesday for the second time in 48 hours.

item.title: U.K.’s New Alcohol Taxes Are Aimed at Keeping Pubs Open and Votes Flowing
item.description: The changes are the biggest shake-up to Britain’s alcohol levies in 140 years, according to a government whose leader was clearly on the campaign trail in announcing them.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak pulling a pint of stout at the Great British Beer Festival in London on Tuesday.

item.title: Chinese Zoo: This Is a Real Sun Bear, Not a Costume
item.description: “Some people think I look too human when I stand up,” the Hangzhou Zoo’s statement said, after a video prompted internet conspiracy theories. “I am a Malayan sun bear!”
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas and Chang Che

item.title: Ukraine’s Grain Lifeline in Danube Ports Comes Under Russia Threat
item.description: Since the collapse of the Black Sea grain deal two weeks ago, small ports on the Danube River are the only shipping outlet for millions of tons of grain.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: The bulk carrier TQ Samsun transiting the Bosporus last month in Istanbul. The TQ Samsun was the last grain ship, carrying corn and rapeseed, to leave Ukraine under the Black Sea grain initiative before Russia halted the program.

item.title: Ousmane Sonko’s Arrest Sets Off New Round of Protests
item.description: Ousmane Sonko, a fiery figure with a loyal youth following, was charged with fomenting insurrection, and his party dissolved.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Dionne Searcey
item.media:description: A police officer detaining a protester during clashes with supporters of Senegal’s opposition leader Ousmane Sonko on Monday in Dakar.

item.title: Under Hindu Nationalist Leaders, Sectarian Violence Flares in India
item.description: A gunman who killed Muslim train passengers and a Hindu march that turned riotous underscore how the partisan stances of India’s top Hindu leaders have given license to chaotic elements in the country.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Relatives of a man who was killed in clashes in Haryana State, India, carrying his body on a stretcher at a hospital in Nuh on Tuesday.

item.title: A Stairway to Nowhere Sells for $32,000 in London
item.description: An entrepreneur saw what others didn’t and now owns the unused set of stairs, which are attached to the back of a suburban building.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: An enclosed stairwell attached to a building in suburban London was sold at auction on Tuesday. Its new owner envisions the space as potentially housing desks for entrepreneurs.

item.title: UNESCO Recommends Venice for Endangered List
item.description: The United Nations’ culture agency is warning of twin perils to the historic city from mass tourism and climate change.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venice’s grand canal. A former government minister said the city had been “fragile,” but was now well placed to face its challenges.

item.title: France Prepares Niger Evacuation Amid Risks of Conflict
item.description: Tensions were rising in the West African nation over demands by African and Western countries to reinstate a president ousted in a military takeover.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh, Elian Peltier and Dionne Searcey
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: Security forces launched tear gas to disperse a pro-junta protest outside the French Embassy in Niamey, the capital of Niger, on Sunday.

item.title: Kerala Lottery: India Sanitation Workers Win $1.2 Million Lottery
item.description: The winners, who are sanitation co-workers in India, each make just a few dollars a day. The jackpot will help them pay off crippling debts.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Mike Ives
item.media:description: A lottery ticket vendor selling tickets in Kochi, Kerala State, India, last year.

item.title: Construction to Break German Dependence on Russian Gas Hits a Snag: Wartime Bombs
item.description: The choreography of finding and clearing unexploded, decades-old munitions has become routine on Germany’s northern coast.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: The liquefied natural gas terminal being built in Wilhelmshaven, in northern Germany, in December.

item.title: Mexico’s ‘Monster’ Trucks Show Cartels Taking Drug War to Next Level
item.description: Taking the monster truck concept to deadly new realms, cartels are modifying pickups with gun turrets, steel armoring and battering rams.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed armored vehicle that had been used by the Jalisco New Generation Cartel, a powerful Mexican criminal group.

item.title: Solar Supply Chain Grows More Opaque Amid Human Rights Concerns
item.description: The global industry is cutting some ties to China, but its exposure to forced labor remains high and companies are less transparent, a new report found.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Ivan Penn
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A JA Solar factory in Hefei, China. A new report found that major solar companies, including JA Solar, are likely to still have extensive exposure to China’s Xinjiang region and potentially to forced labor there.

item.title: ‘Barbenheimer’ Isn’t Funny in Nuclear-Scarred Japan
item.description: The Japanese subsidiary of Warner Bros. criticized what it called insensitive promotion of “Barbie” by the company’s headquarters.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: A movie theater featuring the films “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” in Los Angeles.

item.title: Aung San Suu Kyi Receives Partial Pardon in Myanmar
item.description: The civilian leader, who was ousted in a coup in 2021, had six years cut from a 33-year prison sentence and five of her 19 convictions overturned, state television said.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Aung San Suu Kyi delivering a speech in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, in 2020.

item.title: Typhoon Khanun Lashes Okinawa, Japan, Killing 1 Person
item.description: Typhoon Khanun was hovering near Okinawa Prefecture days after an earlier tropical cyclone, Doksuri, brought death and destruction to China and the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Hikari Hida and Amy Chang Chien

item.title: Russia’s Law Targeting Transgender People Sows Fear for L.G.B.T. Russians
item.description: A new law underscores how Vladimir V. Putin is increasingly using the war in Ukraine as justification for greater restrictions on L.G.B.T.Q. life, portraying it as a consequence of deviant Western values.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Georgy Birger

item.title: Move Over, Men: Women Were Hunters, Too
item.description: Anthropologists are finding that women in modern foraging societies have played a major role in catching game.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The details of Ukraine’s drone strikes.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Ukraine Steps Up Growing Campaign to Strike Within Russia
item.description: The stepped-up drone and missile attacks show a will to hamper the Kremlin’s military logistics, and to remind ordinary Russians of the cost of war.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A house destroyed by shelling in the Russian-controlled region of Donetsk, Ukraine, on Monday.
